segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

segments.pli: “kati nu kho, bhante, lokassa dhammā uppajjamānā uppajjanti ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāyā”ti?
segments.en: “Sir, how many things arise in the world for its harm, suffering, and discomfort?”

segments.pli: “Tayo kho, mahārāja, lokassa dhammā uppajjamānā uppajjanti ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.
segments.en: “Great king, three things arise in the world for its harm, suffering, and discomfort.

segments.pli: Lobho kho, mahārāja, lokassa dhammo, uppajjamāno uppajjati ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.
Doso kho, mahārāja, lokassa dhammo, uppajjamāno uppajjati ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.
Moho kho, mahārāja, lokassa dhammo, uppajjamāno uppajjati ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.
Ime kho, mahārāja, tayo lokassa dhammā uppajjamānā uppajjanti ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāyā”ti.
segments.en: These three things arise in the world for its harm, suffering, and discomfort.”
That is what the Buddha said. …
they harm a person of wicked heart,
as a reed is destroyed by its own fruit.”

suttaplex.blurb: How many things give rise to suffering in oneself?
